Results of the April 15 meeting of the Campus Committee on
Parking, at which seven recommendations from the Student Council
Traffic Commmission were presented, have just been released.
Four recommendations were turned down, two accepted and one
was held for further consideration.
The SC Traffic Commission, - composed of Chairman Arnold
Peinado, Gene Zemsky, and Warren Grupe, drew up the recommendations in an attempt to ease the unsatisfactory parking conditions on
campus. The recommendations were that:
1. Additional parking space be provided along the east side
Of the north-south campus road running from Homewood House to
the Gymnasium, opposite the dormitory. This area to be open. for
Student use.
2. The vacant area immediatelY south of Latrobe Hall be covered with gravel or some suitable
ulaterial to provide temporary additional parking space.
3. A light be placed at the enfrom University Parkway to the
"mints road east of Homewood
Field to permit ease of identification at night.
4. The faculty parking Section
In the area between Levering Hall
and Gilman Hall be abolished 'and
the whole area become available
for transient use.
5. A time limit be placed on
tickets, after which students cannot ask for repeal of fine incurred
aa stated on the traffic ticket
which is now issued. It is suggested that two weeks be the maxiIntim length of time permitted.
6. Forbid those students who
live within eight blocks of the
University from driving to school.
7. Campus police be notified to
hit less stringent during rainy days
When the number of cars on camPus increases.

These include enlargement of

and revisions in membership selection procedures. The constitutional amendments were suggested by

Louis Koerber, president of the
class of 1949 will dedicate Guy
Memorial Walk. The Walk commemorates Mr. Robert F. Guy,
who admired the beauty of the
Hopkins Campus. The benches
along the walk are the gift of the
class of 1949.
There will be an alumni luncheon before the game, and dinners
in the evening for those classes
ending in two and seven. In addition, all fraternities are holding
open house after the game for the
returning graduates.
To round out the weekend for
the undergraduates, the Booster
Club is holding a wiener roast at
Beaver Dam tonight, and the class
of '54 is sponsoring a swimming
party there Sunday afternoon.
"This is the first time that a
complete weekend such as this has
been organized at the Hopkins,"
Gene Zemsky, chairman of the
weekend activities, said.

Last Wednesday's visit of the
Bloodmobile yielded 126 pints of
blood, Student Council member
Warren Grupe announced recently.
Grupe, chairman of the blood
committee, said that the turnout
was not so good as had been expected. Most of those donating
were freshmen, he added.
Each of the students who gave
blood was given a brief physical
checkup first. There were several
nurses on duty, many of them
volunteers, and the donating went

on very smoothly.

Posted throughout the campus
will be used in

informing draft boards of students' class standing, the Registrar
announced Tuesday.
Miss Irene Davis, registrar, explained that since under the New
Plan there are no hard and fast
rules about class standing, the
Deans will judge which class each
student belongs in. This is for
the purpose of draft classification.
Any student who feels that he
should • be placed in a different
class, should contact the Deans
immediately.
1-S Temporary
Miss Davis went on to say that
all students not classified 1-S
should realize this is only a temporary classification. These students will receive a 2-S deferment
this summer, if their class standing is good.
However some men who are
eligible for deferments may be
classified 1-A. They are advised
to file an appeal with their local
board within ten days.

June Week
Descends To
Greek Level
Undergraduate ticket sales for
June Week -'52 were promoted
this week on a fraternity level
with a member from each of the
12 social groups designated as a
special June Week ticket huckster.
The move was prompted by the
need for a larger amount of
funds by May 23, the date set for
the end of the Senior Membership
Drive. It is the expectation of the
June Week Committee that the
JUNE WEEK CALENDAR
Tuesday, June 4—Sport Dance,
Gwynn Oak Park. Dress: Informal.
Wednesday, June 5—Moonlight, Cruise. Leaves from foot
of Broadway. Bay Belle Line.
Thursday, June 6 — Senior
Prom, Alcazar. Dress: Optional.
Saturday, June 8 — Senior
Banquet and Dance, Maryland
Yacht Club. Dress: Formal.
fraternity members expecting to
attend the June Week activities
will respond immediately to the
drive for a more substantial early
sale.
The fraternity drive placed responsibility into the hands of Bill
Fonshell, Frank Cegelski, Ben
Pohlhaus, Ross
Miller, Jack
Jones, John Gassaway, Arnie
Peinado, Don. Peyser, Charlie
Wagner, Gerry Von Stratten, Don
Mantel, and Marty Zavell to sell
undergraduate tickets in their respective fraternities.
Undergraduate strip
tickets,
selling for $8 and representing a
saving of $2 on the price of the
combined total for the individual
events, and single event ducats
remained on sale .at the YMCA
office, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and the
SAC office, 11 a.m. to 1 .p.m.

NEWS-LETTER

Inc DiffiruIics

Hector
(Continued from Page 5)
The next strange circumstance
in Hector's career centers about
his reluctance 'to enter the Domar's automobile. To call this a
naive betrayal of anti-capitalist
sentiments is hardly beyond the
pale of reasonable conjecture.
During the first few weeks of
his residence with them, the Domars noted the following quirks in
Hector's behavior: (1) uncanny
fear of going up and down steps;
(2) refusal to enter the kitchen;
(3) refusal to enter the bathroom; (4) intense hatred and mistrust of policemen.
An explanation put forth by
one school of thought is that Hector, a creature of foreign extraction (Germany, it is well known,
was the couch of Nazism and the
cradle of the communist prophet),
was markedly unused to the
simple, capitalist luxuries of life:
automobiles, kitchen sinks, bathtubs, the very commonplaces of
our free .society. It is this group
of theorists who maintain that
Hector is quite capable of following the party leash.
As for his dislike of autos and
policemen, we were informed that
he had recently been involved in
an accident, in 'which both cars
and a policeman figured. Possibly,
it was suggested, he associated
both with unpleasantness. From
our point of view, however, attributing subconscious motivations to a mere dog does not seem
either wholesome or realistic.
We here rest our case, temporarily. Met with the stubborn refusal of Hector to cooperate, halted by his tendency to answer evasively, we have tried to be unbiased. Is it merely coincidence
that his suspect origins are impossible to pin -down accurately,
and that he maintains a sly attitude of silence in an institution
devoted to words? Is it merely
coincidence that his master is a
professor of Political Economy?

IRC Elections Declared
Constitutionally Illegal
As the climax of a year of financial and internal troubles, the International Relations Club elections held on May 6 have been successfully contested and new elections will be held Monday at 8
p.m. in the Sherwood Room.
Charles Carlson took the presidential post, Ted Wilson became
business manager and Bob Palmer secretary in the contested
running.
SAC Rules
The opposition to the first elections was led by I. William Zartman and composed of most old
members of the club. Their objections were based on the SAC
by-laws for elections, sections 2a
and 2b. Section 2a makes the provision that all elections must be
supervised by a member of the
SAC.
Section 2b says, "Any candidate
for a board of control position
who feels that he can present conclusive evidence that he was kept
out of office by a political bloc of
any kind whatsoaver, may appeal
Lis case to the Student Activities
Committee."

in the evening for those classes
ending in two and seven. In addition, all fraternities are holding
open house after the game for the
returning graduates.

the undergraduates, the Booster
Club is holding a wiener roast at
Beaver Dam tonight, and the class
of '54 is sponsoring a swimming
party there Sunday afternoon.

complete weekend such as this has
been organized at the Hopkins,"
Gene Zemsky, chairman of the
weekend activities, said.

Posted throughout the campus

informing draft boards of students' class standing, the Registrar

Miss Irene Davis, registrar, explained that since under the New
Plan there are no hard and fast
rules about class standing, the
Deans will judge which class each
student belongs in. This is for
the purpose of draft classification.

should • be placed in a different
class, should contact the Deans
immediately.
1-S Temporary
Miss Davis went on to say that
all students not classified 1-S
should realize this is only a temporary classification. These students will receive a 2-S deferment
this summer, if their class standing is good.
However some men who are
eligible for deferments may be
classified 1-A. They are advised
to file an appeal with their local
board within ten days.

June Week
Descends To
Greek Level
Undergraduate ticket sales for
June Week -'52 were promoted
this week on a fraternity level
with a member from each of the
12 social groups designated as a
special June Week ticket huckster.
The move was prompted by the
need for a larger amount of
funds by May 23, the date set for
the end of the Senior Membership
Drive. It is the expectation of the
June Week Committee that the
JUNE WEEK CALENDAR
Tuesday, June 4—Sport Dance,
Gwynn Oak Park. Dress: Informal.
Wednesday, June 5—Moonlight, Cruise. Leaves from foot
of Broadway. Bay Belle Line.
Thursday, June 6 — Senior
Prom, Alcazar. Dress: Optional.
Saturday, June 8 — Senior
Banquet and Dance, Maryland
Yacht Club. Dress: Formal.
fraternity members expecting to
attend the June Week activities
will respond immediately to the
drive for a more substantial early
sale.
The fraternity drive placed responsibility into the hands of Bill
Fonshell, Frank Cegelski, Ben
Pohlhaus, Ross
Miller, Jack
Jones, John Gassaway, Arnie
Peinado, Don. Peyser, Charlie
Wagner, Gerry Von Stratten, Don
Mantel, and Marty Zavell to sell
undergraduate tickets in their respective fraternities.
Undergraduate strip
tickets,
selling for $8 and representing a
saving of $2 on the price of the
combined total for the individual
events, and single event ducats
remained on sale .at the YMCA
office, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and the
SAC office, 11 a.m. to 1 .p.m.

NEWS-LETTER

Inc DiffiruIics

Hector
(Continued from Page 5)
The next strange circumstance
in Hector's career centers about
his reluctance 'to enter the Domar's automobile. To call this a
naive betrayal of anti-capitalist
sentiments is hardly beyond the
pale of reasonable conjecture.
During the first few weeks of
his residence with them, the Domars noted the following quirks in
Hector's behavior: (1) uncanny
fear of going up and down steps;
(2) refusal to enter the kitchen;
(3) refusal to enter the bathroom; (4) intense hatred and mistrust of policemen.
An explanation put forth by
one school of thought is that Hector, a creature of foreign extraction (Germany, it is well known,
was the couch of Nazism and the
cradle of the communist prophet),
was markedly unused to the
simple, capitalist luxuries of life:
automobiles, kitchen sinks, bathtubs, the very commonplaces of
our free .society. It is this group
of theorists who maintain that
Hector is quite capable of following the party leash.
As for his dislike of autos and
policemen, we were informed that
he had recently been involved in
an accident, in 'which both cars
and a policeman figured. Possibly,
it was suggested, he associated
both with unpleasantness. From
our point of view, however, attributing subconscious motivations to a mere dog does not seem
either wholesome or realistic.
We here rest our case, temporarily. Met with the stubborn refusal of Hector to cooperate, halted by his tendency to answer evasively, we have tried to be unbiased. Is it merely coincidence
that his suspect origins are impossible to pin -down accurately,
and that he maintains a sly attitude of silence in an institution
devoted to words? Is it merely
coincidence that his master is a
professor of Political Economy?

IRC Elections Declared
Constitutionally Illegal
As the climax of a year of financial and internal troubles, the International Relations Club elections held on May 6 have been successfully contested and new elections will be held Monday at 8
p.m. in the Sherwood Room.
Charles Carlson took the presidential post, Ted Wilson became
business manager and Bob Palmer secretary in the contested
running.
SAC Rules
The opposition to the first elections was led by I. William Zartman and composed of most old
members of the club. Their objections were based on the SAC
by-laws for elections, sections 2a
and 2b. Section 2a makes the provision that all elections must be
supervised by a member of the
SAC.
Section 2b says, "Any candidate
for a board of control position
who feels that he can present conclusive evidence that he was kept
out of office by a political bloc of
any kind whatsoaver, may appeal
Lis case to the Student Activities
Committee."

unearned. The victory gave Carlson a 1-2 record for the year.

Maryland will field two of the
men who were responsible the
most for the 6-1 beating the JayS
